æ¥šä¹‹å…ˆç¥–å‡ºè‡ªå¸é¡“é Šé«˜é™½ã€‚ é«˜é™½è€…ï¼Œé»ƒå¸ä¹‹å­«ï¼Œæ˜Œæ„ä¹‹å­ä¹Ÿã€‚ é«˜é™½ç”Ÿç¨±ï¼Œç¨±ç”Ÿå·ç« ï¼Œå·ç« ç”Ÿé‡é»ã€‚ é‡é»ç‚ºå¸åš³é«˜è¾›å±…ç«æ­£ï¼Œç”šæœ‰åŠŸï¼Œèƒ½å…‰èå¤©ä¸‹ï¼Œå¸åš³å‘½æ›°ç¥èã€‚ å…±å·¥æ°ä½œäº‚ï¼Œå¸åš³ä½¿é‡é»èª…ä¹‹è€Œä¸ç›¡ã€‚ å¸ä¹ƒä»¥åºšå¯…æ—¥èª…é‡é»ï¼Œè€Œä»¥å…¶å¼Ÿå³å›ç‚ºé‡é»å¾Œï¼Œå¾©å±…ç«æ­£ï¼Œç‚ºç¥èã€‚
The Chu family's ancestral origins trace back to Emperor Zhuanxu Gao Yang. Gao Yang was the grandson of the Yellow Emperor and son of Chang Yi. Gao Yang fathered Chen, who fathered Juan Zhang, who fathered Chong Li. Chong Li served as Minister of Fire under Emperor Ku Gao Xin and achieved great merit, being able to illuminate and unite the whole world. Emperor Ku named him Zhu Rong. When the Gong Gong clan rebelled, Emperor Ku ordered Chong Li to suppress them, but he did not completely succeed. The emperor then executed Chong Li on the day Geng Yin, and appointed Chong Li's younger brother Wu Hui as his successor to serve as Minister of Fire, becoming Zhu Rong.
2
å³å›ç”Ÿé™¸çµ‚ã€‚ é™¸çµ‚ç”Ÿå­å…­äººï¼Œå¼å‰–è€Œç”¢ç„‰ã€‚ å…¶é•·ä¸€æ›°æ˜†å¾ï¼› äºŒæ›°åƒèƒ¡ï¼› ä¸‰æ›°å½­ç¥–ï¼› å››æ›°æœƒäººï¼› äº”æ›°æ›¹å§“ï¼› å…­æ›°å­£é€£ï¼Œç¾‹å§“ï¼Œæ¥šå…¶å¾Œä¹Ÿã€‚ æ˜†å¾æ°ï¼Œå¤ä¹‹æ™‚å˜—ç‚ºä¾¯ä¼¯ï¼Œæ¡€ä¹‹æ™‚æ¹¯æ»…ä¹‹ã€‚ å½­ç¥–æ°ï¼Œæ®·ä¹‹æ™‚å˜—ç‚ºä¾¯ä¼¯ï¼Œæ®·ä¹‹æœ«ä¸–æ»…å½­ç¥–æ°ã€‚ å­£é€£ç”Ÿé™„æ²®ï¼Œé™„æ²®ç”Ÿç©´ç†Šã€‚ å…¶å¾Œä¸­å¾®ï¼Œæˆ–åœ¨ä¸­åœ‹ï¼Œæˆ–åœ¨è »å¤·ï¼Œå¼—èƒ½ç´€å…¶ä¸–ã€‚
Wu Hui fathered Lu Zhong. Lu Zhong fathered six sons, who were born by splitting open his body. The eldest was named Kun Wu; the second Can Hu; the third Peng Zu; the fourth Hui Ren; the fifth Cao Xing; the sixth Ji Lian of the Mi surname, from whom Chu descended. The Kun Wu clan served as marquises during the Xia dynasty, but King Jie destroyed them during the time of Tang. The Peng Zu clan served as marquises during the Yin dynasty, but were destroyed at the end of the Yin period. Ji Lian fathered Fu Ju, who fathered Xue Xiong. Afterward their line declined, sometimes residing among the Chinese, sometimes among the barbarians, so their generations cannot be clearly traced.
3
å‘¨æ–‡ç‹ä¹‹æ™‚ï¼Œå­£é€£ä¹‹è‹—è£”æ›°é¬»ç†Šã€‚ é¬»ç†Šå­äº‹æ–‡ç‹ï¼Œèš¤å’ã€‚ å…¶å­æ›°ç†Šéº—ã€‚ ç†Šéº—ç”Ÿç†Šç‹‚ï¼Œç†Šç‹‚ç”Ÿç†Šç¹¹ã€‚ ç†Šç¹¹ç•¶å‘¨æˆç‹ä¹‹æ™‚ï¼Œèˆ‰æ–‡ã€æ­¦å‹¤å‹ä¹‹å¾Œå—£ï¼Œè€Œå°ç†Šç¹¹æ–¼æ¥šè »ï¼Œå°ä»¥å­ç”·ä¹‹ç”°ï¼Œå§“ç¾‹æ°ï¼Œå±…ä¸¹é™½ã€‚ æ¥šå­ç†Šç¹¹èˆ‡é­¯å…¬ä¼¯ç¦½ã€è¡›åº·å”å­ç‰Ÿã€æ™‰ä¾¯ç‡®ã€é½Šå¤ªå…¬å­å‘‚ä¼‹ä¿±äº‹æˆç‹ã€‚
During the time of King Wen of Zhou, Ji Lian's descendant was named Yu Xiong. Yu Xiong served King Wen but died young. His son was named Xiong Li. Xiong Li fathered Xiong Kuang, who fathered Xiong Xi. During the time of King Cheng of Zhou, because of the meritorious service of Wen and Wu, Xiong Xi was enfeoffed in Chu among the barbarians, given territory of the rank of zi and nan, with the surname Mi, and resided in Dan Yang. The Chu lord Xiong Xi, along with Duke Bo Qin of Lu, Zi Mu of Wei Kang Shu, Hou Xie of Jin, and Tai Zi LÃ¼ Ji of Qi, all served King Cheng.

ç†Šç¹¹ç”Ÿç†Šè‰¾ï¼Œç†Šè‰¾ç”Ÿç†Šäº¶ï¼Œç†Šäº¶ç”Ÿç†Šå‹ã€‚ ç†Šå‹ä»¥å¼Ÿç†Šæ¥Šç‚ºå¾Œã€‚ ç†Šæ¥Šç”Ÿç†Šæ¸ ã€‚
Xiong Xi fathered Xiong Ai, who fathered Xiong Dan, who fathered Xiong Sheng. Xiong Sheng made his younger brother Xiong Yang his successor. Xiong Yang fathered Xiong Qu.

ç†Šæ¸ ç”Ÿå­ä¸‰å¹´ã€‚ ç•¶å‘¨å¤·ç‹ä¹‹æ™‚ï¼Œç‹å®¤å¾®ï¼Œè«¸ä¾¯æˆ–ä¸æœï¼Œç›¸ä¼ã€‚ ç†Šæ¸ ç”šå¾—æ±Ÿæ¼¢é–’æ°‘å’Œï¼Œä¹ƒèˆˆå…µä¼åº¸ã€æ¥Šè †ï¼Œè‡³äºé„‚ã€‚ ç†Šæ¸ æ›°ï¼šã€Œæˆ‘è »å¤·ä¹Ÿï¼Œä¸èˆ‡ä¸­åœ‹ä¹‹è™Ÿè¬šã€‚ã€ ä¹ƒç«‹å…¶é•·å­åº·ç‚ºå¥äº¶ç‹ï¼Œä¸­å­ç´…ç‚ºé„‚ç‹ï¼Œå°‘å­åŸ·ç–µç‚ºè¶Šç« ç‹ï¼Œçš†åœ¨æ±Ÿä¸Šæ¥šè »ä¹‹åœ°ã€‚ åŠå‘¨å²ç‹ä¹‹æ™‚ï¼Œæš´è™ï¼Œç†Šæ¸ ç•å…¶ä¼æ¥šï¼Œäº¦å»å…¶ç‹ã€‚
Xiong Qu lived for three years after fathering a son. During the time of King Yi of Zhou, the royal house declined, and the feudal lords sometimes failed to attend court and attacked each other. Xiong Qu greatly won the favor of the people between the Jiang and Han rivers, so he raised troops to attack Yong, Yang Wei, reaching as far as E. Xiong Qu said: 'I am a barbarian, so I do not use the titles and posthumous names of China.' Therefore he established his eldest son Kang as King of Ju Dian, his middle son Hong as King of E, and his youngest son Zhi Ci as King of Yue Zhang, all within the Chu barbarian lands along the Jiang River. When King Li of Zhou became tyrannical, Xiong Qu feared he would attack Chu, so he also removed their royal titles.

å¾Œç‚ºç†Šæ¯‹åº·ï¼Œæ¯‹åº·èš¤æ­»ã€‚ ç†Šæ¸ å’ï¼Œå­ç†Šæ‘¯ç´…ç«‹ã€‚ æ‘¯ç´…å’ï¼Œå…¶å¼Ÿå¼’è€Œä»£ç«‹ï¼Œæ›°ç†Šå»¶ã€‚ ç†Šå»¶ç”Ÿç†Šå‹‡ã€‚
Later he became Xiong Wu Kang, but Wu Kang died young. Xiong Qu died, and his son Xiong Zhi Hong succeeded him. Zhi Hong died, and his younger brother assassinated him and took the throne, calling himself Xiong Yan. Xiong Yan fathered Xiong Yong.

In Xiong Yong's sixth year, the Zhou people rebelled, attacking King Li, who fled to Zhi. In Xiong Yong's tenth year, he died, and his younger brother Xiong Yan succeeded him.

In Xiong Yan's tenth year, he died. He had four sons: the eldest Bo Shuang, the second Zhong Xue, the third Shu Kan, and the youngest Ji Xun. When Xiong Yan died, the eldest son Bo Shuang succeeded him, becoming Xiong Shuang.

In Xiong Shuang's first year, King Xuan of Zhou first ascended the throne. In Xiong Shuang's sixth year, he died, and the three younger brothers contended for the throne. Zhong Xue died; Shu Kan fled and took refuge in Pu; and the youngest Ji Xun succeeded, becoming Xiong Xun. In Xiong Xun's sixteenth year, Duke Huan of Zheng was first enfeoffed in Zheng. In the twenty-second year, Xiong Xun died, and his son Xiong E succeeded him. In Xiong E's first year, Duke Zhuang of Zheng died.

In the second year, Xiong E died, and his younger brother Xiong Xue succeeded him.

In Xiong Xue's first year, King You of Zhou was in power. In the second year, the Quanrong attacked and killed King You, and the Zhou moved eastward. In the third year, Xiong Xue died, and his son Xiong Kan succeeded him. In Xiong Kan's first year, Duke Xiang of Qin died. In the fifth year, Xiong Kan died, and his son Xiong Yuan succeeded him.

In Xiong Yuan's first year, Duke Wen of Qin died. In the tenth year, Xiong Yuan died, and his son Xiong Qu succeeded him. In Xiong Qu's first year, Duke Mu of Qin died. In the tenth year, Xiong Qu died, and his son Xiong Zi succeeded him. In Xiong Zi's first year, Duke Kang of Qin died. In the twelfth year, Xiong Zi died, and his son Xiong Wei succeeded him.

In Xiong Wei's first year, Duke Gong of Qin died. In the twelfth year, Xiong Wei died, and his son Xiong Ao succeeded him. In Xiong Ao's first year, Duke Jing of Qin died. In the twelfth year, Xiong Shang died, and his son Xiong Yan succeeded him.

In Xiong Heng's first year, Duke Zhao of Qin died. In the thirtieth year, Xiong Heng died, and his son Xiong Shang succeeded him. He extinguished Kui, because Kui did not sacrifice to Zhu Rong and Yu Xiong.

å¤ï¼Œä¼å®‹ï¼Œå®‹å‘Šæ€¥æ–¼æ™‰ï¼Œæ™‰æ•‘å®‹ï¼Œæˆç‹ç½·æ­¸ã€‚ å°‡è»å­ç‰è«‹æˆ°ï¼Œæˆç‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œé‡è€³äº¡å±…å¤–ä¹…ï¼Œå’å¾—ååœ‹ï¼Œå¤©ä¹‹æ‰€é–‹ï¼Œä¸å¯ç•¶ã€‚ã€ å­ç‰å›ºè«‹ï¼Œä¹ƒèˆ‡ä¹‹å°‘å¸«è€Œå»ã€‚ æ™‰æœæ•—å­ç‰æ–¼åŸæ¿®ã€‚ æˆç‹æ€’ï¼Œèª…å­ç‰ã€‚
In summer, he attacked Song, and Song urgently appealed to Jin for help. Jin rescued Song, so Cheng Wang withdrew and returned. General Zi Yu requested to fight, but Cheng Wang said: 'Chong Er has been exiled abroad for a long time, and now suddenly returns to his country. This is Heaven's will - we cannot oppose it.' Zi Yu persistently requested, so he gave him a small force and sent him away. Jin indeed defeated Zi Yu at Cheng Pu. Cheng Wang was angry and executed Zi Yu.

å››åå…­å¹´ï¼Œåˆï¼Œæˆç‹å°‡ä»¥å•†è‡£ç‚ºå¤ªå­ï¼Œèªä»¤å°¹å­ä¸Šã€‚ å­ä¸Šæ›°ï¼šã€Œå›ä¹‹é½’æœªä¹Ÿï¼Œè€Œåˆå¤šå…§å¯µï¼Œçµ€ä¹ƒäº‚ä¹Ÿã€‚ æ¥šåœ‹ä¹‹èˆ‰å¸¸åœ¨å°‘è€…ã€‚ ä¸”å•†è‡£èœ‚ç›®è€Œè±ºè²ï¼Œå¿äººä¹Ÿï¼Œä¸å¯ç«‹ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ ç‹ä¸è½ï¼Œç«‹ä¹‹ã€‚ å¾Œåˆæ¬²ç«‹å­è·è€Œçµ€å¤ªå­å•†è‡£ã€‚ å•†è‡£èè€Œæœªå¯©ä¹Ÿï¼Œå‘Šå…¶å‚…æ½˜å´‡æ›°ï¼šã€Œä½•ä»¥å¾—å…¶å¯¦ï¼Ÿã€ å´‡æ›°ï¼šã€Œé¥—ç‹ä¹‹å¯µå§¬æ±Ÿç¾‹è€Œå‹¿æ•¬ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ å•†è‡£å¾ä¹‹ã€‚ æ±Ÿç¾‹æ€’æ›°ï¼šã€Œå®œä¹ç‹ä¹‹æ¬²æ®ºè‹¥è€Œç«‹è·ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ å•†è‡£å‘Šæ½˜å´‡æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¿¡çŸ£ã€‚ã€ å´‡æ›°ï¼šã€Œèƒ½äº‹ä¹‹ä¹ï¼Ÿã€ æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸èƒ½ã€‚ã€ ã€Œèƒ½äº¡å»ä¹ï¼Ÿã€ æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸èƒ½ã€‚ã€ ã€Œèƒ½è¡Œå¤§äº‹ä¹ï¼Ÿã€ æ›°ï¼šã€Œèƒ½ã€‚ã€ å†¬åæœˆï¼Œå•†è‡£ä»¥å®®è¡›å…µåœæˆç‹ã€‚ æˆç‹è«‹é£Ÿç†Šè¹¯è€Œæ­»ï¼Œä¸è½ã€‚ ä¸æœªï¼Œæˆç‹è‡ªçµæ®ºã€‚ å•†è‡£ä»£ç«‹ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºç©†ç‹ã€‚
In the forty-sixth year, initially Cheng Wang intended to make Shang Chen his crown prince, and discussed it with Prime Minister Zi Shang. Zi Shang said: 'Your Majesty is not yet old, and moreover you have many favored concubines. If you demote him, it will cause disorder. In the state of Chu, the ruler is always chosen from among the younger sons. Moreover, Shang Chen has wasp-like eyes and the voice of a wolf - he is a cruel man and cannot be established.' The king did not listen and established him as crown prince. Later he again wished to establish Zi Zhi and demote Crown Prince Shang Chen. Shang Chen heard this but was not certain, so he told his tutor Pan Chong: 'How can I learn the truth?' Chong said: 'Feast the king's favored concubine Jiang Mi but do not show her respect.' Shang Chen followed this advice. Jiang Mi was angry and said: 'No wonder the king wishes to kill you and establish Zhi.' Shang Chen told Pan Chong: 'It is true.' Chong said: 'Can you serve him?' He said: 'I cannot.' 'Can you flee and leave?' He said: 'I cannot.' 'Can you carry out great deeds?' He said: 'I can.' In winter, tenth month, Shang Chen used the palace guards to surround Cheng Wang. Cheng Wang requested to eat bear paw and die, but they would not listen. On Ding Wei, Cheng Wang strangled himself and died. Shang Chen succeeded to the throne, becoming Mu Wang.
25
ç©†ç‹ç«‹ï¼Œä»¥å…¶å¤ªå­å®®äºˆæ½˜å´‡ï¼Œä½¿ç‚ºå¤ªå¸«ï¼ŒæŒåœ‹äº‹ã€‚ ç©†ç‹ä¸‰å¹´ï¼Œæ»…æ±Ÿã€‚ å››å¹´ï¼Œæ»…å…­ã€è“¼ã€‚ å…­ã€è“¼ï¼Œçš‹é™¶ä¹‹å¾Œã€‚ å…«å¹´ï¼Œä¼é™³ã€‚ åäºŒå¹´ï¼Œå’ã€‚ å­èŠç‹ä¾¶ç«‹ã€‚
Mu Wang ascended the throne and gave his former palace to Pan Chong, appointing him as Grand Tutor to manage state affairs. In Mu Wang's third year, he extinguished Jiang. In the fourth year, he extinguished Liu and Liao. Liu and Liao were descendants of Gao Tao. In the eighth year, he attacked Chen. In the twelfth year, he died. His son Zhuang Wang LÃ¼ ascended the throne.

èŠç‹å³ä½ä¸‰å¹´ï¼Œä¸å‡ºè™Ÿä»¤ï¼Œæ—¥å¤œç‚ºæ¨‚ï¼Œä»¤åœ‹ä¸­æ›°ï¼šã€Œæœ‰æ•¢è««è€…æ­»ç„¡èµ¦ï¼ã€ ä¼èˆ‰å…¥è««ã€‚ èŠç‹å·¦æŠ±é„­å§¬ï¼Œå³æŠ±è¶Šå¥³ï¼Œåé˜é¼“ä¹‹é–’ã€‚ ä¼èˆ‰æ›°ï¼šã€Œé¡˜æœ‰é€²éš±ã€‚ã€ æ›°ï¼šã€Œæœ‰é³¥åœ¨æ–¼é˜œï¼Œä¸‰å¹´ä¸èœšä¸é³´ï¼Œæ˜¯ä½•é³¥ä¹Ÿï¼Ÿã€ èŠç‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸‰å¹´ä¸èœšï¼Œèœšå°‡æ²–å¤©ï¼› ä¸‰å¹´ä¸é³´ï¼Œé³´å°‡é©šäººã€‚ èˆ‰é€€çŸ£ï¼Œå¾çŸ¥ä¹‹çŸ£ã€‚ã€ å±…æ•¸æœˆï¼Œæ·«ç›Šç”šã€‚ å¤§å¤«è˜‡å¾ä¹ƒå…¥è««ã€‚ ç‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œè‹¥ä¸èä»¤ä¹ï¼Ÿã€ å°æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ®ºèº«ä»¥æ˜å›ï¼Œè‡£ä¹‹é¡˜ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ æ–¼æ˜¯ä¹ƒç½·æ·«æ¨‚ï¼Œè½æ”¿ï¼Œæ‰€èª…è€…æ•¸ç™¾äººï¼Œæ‰€é€²è€…æ•¸ç™¾äººï¼Œä»»ä¼èˆ‰ã€è˜‡å¾ä»¥æ”¿ï¼Œåœ‹äººå¤§èªªã€‚ æ˜¯æ­²æ»…åº¸ã€‚ å…­å¹´ï¼Œä¼å®‹ï¼Œç²äº”ç™¾ä¹˜ã€‚
Zhuang Wang ascended the throne but for three years issued no commands, spending day and night in pleasure, and commanded the state: 'Anyone who dares remonstrate will be executed without pardon!' Wu Ju entered to remonstrate. Zhuang Wang was embracing the Zheng beauty on his left and the Yue beauty on his right, seated among bells and drums. Wu Ju said: 'I wish to present a riddle.' He said: 'There is a bird perched on a mound. For three years it does not fly, does not sing. What bird is this?' Zhuang Wang said: 'For three years it does not fly, but when it flies it will soar to heaven; for three years it does not sing, but when it sings it will astonish people. You may retire - I understand.' After several months, his debauchery became even worse. The grand master Su Cong then entered to remonstrate. The king said: 'Have you not heard the command?' He replied: 'To die to enlighten my lord is my wish as a minister.' Thereupon he stopped the debauchery and music, attended to government affairs, executed several hundred people, promoted several hundred people, entrusted Wu Ju and Su Cong with administration, and the people of the state were greatly pleased. This year he extinguished Yong. In the sixth year, he attacked Song and captured five hundred chariots.

In the eighth year, he attacked Lu Hun Rong, reaching as far as Luo, and reviewed his troops in the Zhou suburbs. Zhou dispatched Wang Zi Man to inquire, saying: 'What is the meaning of this?' The king replied: 'I have heard that you have treasures of jade and silk, I have come to request them.' Wang Zi Man said: 'Do you have a command?' The king said: 'No command.' Wang Zi Man said: 'The Son of Heaven has a command, and the feudal lords respond to it. Now you have no command and come to request - this is called robbery.' Zhuang Wang said: 'You speak well.' Then he withdrew his troops. In the fourteenth year, Zhuang Wang died, and his son Gong Wang Shen ascended the throne. Gong Wang's first year, he attacked Song. In the twelfth year, Gong Wang died, and his son Kang Wang Zhao ascended the throne. Kang Wang's first year, he attacked Sui. In the second year, he extinguished Huang. In the sixth year, he attacked Song and besieged Min Mian. In the ninth year, Kang Wang died, and his son Ling Wang Wei ascended the throne. Ling Wang's first year, he attacked Chen. In the fourth year, he attacked Sui.

Kang Wang favored his younger brothers Gong Zi Wei, Zi Bi, Zi Xi, and Qi Ji. In Ling Wang's third year, sixth month, Chu sent envoys to Jin requesting to assemble the feudal lords. All the feudal lords assembled with Chu at Shen. Wu Ju said: 'In ancient times, Xia Jie had the banquet at Gou Tai, Shang Tang had the mandate at Jing Bo, Zhou Wu Wang had the oath at Meng Jin, Cheng Wang had the meeting at Qi Yang, Kang Wang had the court at Feng Gong, Mu Wang had the assembly at Tu Shan, Duke Huan of Qi had the army at Zhao Ling, Duke Wen of Jin had the alliance at Jian Tu. What will our lord use?' Ling Wang said: 'Use Duke Huan's method.' At this time, Zi Chan of Zheng was present. Thereupon Jin, Song, Lu, and Wei did not attend. After Ling Wang concluded the alliance, he showed arrogant bearing. Wu Ju said: 'Jie held the assembly at You Ren, and Yin rebelled against him. Zhou held the assembly at Li Shan, and the eastern Yi rebelled against him. King You held the alliance at Tai Shi, and the Rong and Di rebelled against him. In the eighth year, he sent Gong Zi Qi Ji to lead troops and extinguish Chen. In the tenth year, he summoned the Marquis of Cai, got him drunk, and killed him. He had Qi Ji pacify Cai and made him Duke of Chen and Cai.

In the eleventh year, he attacked Xu to intimidate Wu. Ling Wang camped at Qian Xi to await them. The king said: 'Qi, Jin, Lu, and Wei all received precious vessels when they were enfeoffed, but I alone did not. Now I will send envoys to Zhou to request the ding tripod to divide it - will they give it to me?' Xi Fu replied: 'They will certainly give it to Your Majesty! In ancient times, our ancestor Xiong Xi took refuge in Jing Shan, dwelling in thatched huts and eating coarse food among the weeds and grass, traversing mountains and forests to serve the Son of Heaven, offering only peach bows and thorn arrows for the royal service. Qi is the king's maternal uncle; Jin and Lu and Wei are the king's maternal younger brothers: this is why Chu has no share while they all have some. Now Zhou together with the four states serves Your Majesty, they will follow your commands - how dare they begrudge the ding?' Ling Wang said: 'In ancient times, my royal ancestor Bo Fu Kun Wu originally dwelt in this region, but now the people of Zheng greedily keep their fields and will not give them to me. Now if I request them, will they give them to me?' He replied: 'Zhou does not begrudge the ding, how dare Zheng begrudge the fields?' Ling Wang said: 'In ancient times the feudal lords were distant from me and feared Jin, but now I greatly fortify Chen and Cai and Bu Geng, each with a thousand chariots in military strength - will the feudal lords fear me?' He replied: 'They will fear you!' Ling Wang was pleased and said: 'Xi Fu speaks well of ancient affairs.'

In the twelfth year, spring, Chu Ling Wang enjoyed Qian Xi so much he could not leave. The people of the state suffered from the forced labor. Initially, Ling Wang assembled troops at Shen and executed the Yue grand master Chang Shou Guo, killed the Cai grand master Guan Qi. Qi's son Cong fled to Wu and persuaded the Wu king to attack Chu, creating discord between the Yue grand master Chang Shou Guo to cause rebellion, creating a gap for Wu. He forged orders from Gong Zi Qi Ji to summon Gong Zi Bi from Jin, reaching Cai, wanting to attack Cai with Wu and Yue troops. He commanded Gong Zi Bi to meet Qi Ji and form an alliance at Deng. Ling Wang heard of the rebellion and returned from Qian Xi, camping at Ping Rao. Qing Feng of Qi was at Chu at the time, so Ling Wang consulted him. Qing Feng said: 'It is better to pardon them and let them come to court, then we can observe their intentions.' Ling Wang sent someone to summon them, but they did not come. He sent Gong Zi Zi Gao to observe their situation.

åˆï¼Œå­æ¯”è‡ªæ™‰æ­¸ï¼ŒéŸ“å®£å­å•å”å‘æ›°ï¼šã€Œå­æ¯”å…¶æ¿Ÿä¹ï¼Ÿã€ å°æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸å°±ã€‚ã€ å®£å­æ›°ï¼šã€ŒåŒæƒ¡ç›¸æ±‚ï¼Œå¦‚å¸‚è³ˆç„‰ï¼Œä½•ç‚ºä¸å°±ï¼Ÿã€ å°æ›°ï¼šã€Œç„¡èˆ‡åŒå¥½ï¼Œèª°èˆ‡åŒæƒ¡ï¼Ÿ å–åœ‹æœ‰äº”é›£ï¼šæœ‰å¯µç„¡äººï¼Œä¸€ä¹Ÿï¼› æœ‰äººç„¡ä¸»ï¼ŒäºŒä¹Ÿï¼› æœ‰ä¸»ç„¡è¬€ï¼Œä¸‰ä¹Ÿï¼› æœ‰è¬€è€Œç„¡æ°‘ï¼Œå››ä¹Ÿï¼› æœ‰æ°‘è€Œç„¡å¾·ï¼Œäº”ä¹Ÿã€‚ å­æ¯”åœ¨æ™‰åä¸‰å¹´çŸ£ï¼Œæ™‰ã€æ¥šä¹‹å¾ä¸èé€šè€…ï¼Œå¯è¬‚ç„¡äººçŸ£ï¼› æ—ç›¡è¦ªå›ï¼Œå¯è¬‚ç„¡ä¸»çŸ£ï¼› ç„¡é‡è€Œå‹•ï¼Œå¯è¬‚ç„¡è¬€çŸ£ï¼› ç‚ºç¾ˆçµ‚ä¸–ï¼Œå¯è¬‚ç„¡æ°‘çŸ£ï¼› äº¡ç„¡æ„›å¾µï¼Œå¯è¬‚ç„¡å¾·çŸ£ã€‚ ç‹è™è€Œä¸å¿Œï¼Œå­æ¯”æ¶‰äº”é›£ä»¥å¼’å›ï¼Œèª°èƒ½æ¿Ÿä¹‹ï¼ æœ‰æ¥šåœ‹è€…ï¼Œå…¶æ£„ç–¾ä¹ï¼Ÿ å›é™³ã€è”¡ï¼Œæ–¹åŸå¤–å±¬ç„‰ã€‚ è‹›æ…ä¸ä½œï¼Œç›œè³Šä¼éš±ï¼Œç§æ¬²ä¸é•ï¼Œæ°‘ç„¡æ€¨å¿ƒã€‚ å…ˆç¥å‘½ä¹‹ï¼Œåœ‹æ°‘ä¿¡ä¹‹ã€‚ ç¾‹å§“æœ‰äº‚ï¼Œå¿…å­£å¯¦ç«‹ï¼Œæ¥šä¹‹å¸¸ä¹Ÿã€‚ å­æ¯”ä¹‹å®˜ï¼Œå‰‡å³å°¹ä¹Ÿï¼› æ•¸å…¶è²´å¯µï¼Œå‰‡åº¶å­ä¹Ÿï¼› ä»¥ç¥æ‰€å‘½ï¼Œå‰‡åˆé ä¹‹ï¼› æ°‘ç„¡æ‡·ç„‰ï¼Œå°‡ä½•ä»¥ç«‹ï¼Ÿã€ å®£å­æ›°ï¼šã€Œé½Šæ¡“ã€æ™‰æ–‡ä¸äº¦æ˜¯ä¹ï¼Ÿã€ å°æ›°ï¼šã€Œé½Šæ¡“ï¼Œè¡›å§¬ä¹‹å­ä¹Ÿï¼Œæœ‰å¯µæ–¼é‡å…¬ã€‚ æœ‰é®‘å”ç‰™ã€è³“é ˆç„¡ã€éš°æœ‹ä»¥ç‚ºè¼”ï¼Œæœ‰è’ã€è¡›ä»¥ç‚ºå¤–ä¸»ï¼Œæœ‰é«˜ã€åœ‹ä»¥ç‚ºå…§ä¸»ã€‚ å¾å–„å¦‚æµï¼Œæ–½æƒ ä¸å€¦ã€‚ æœ‰åœ‹ï¼Œä¸äº¦å®œä¹ï¼Ÿ æ˜”æˆ‘æ–‡å…¬ï¼Œç‹å­£å§¬ä¹‹å­ä¹Ÿï¼Œæœ‰å¯µæ–¼ç»å…¬ã€‚ å¥½å­¸ä¸å€¦ã€‚ ç”Ÿåä¸ƒå¹´ï¼Œæœ‰å£«äº”äººï¼Œæœ‰å…ˆå¤§å¤«å­é¤˜ã€å­çŠ¯ä»¥ç‚ºè…¹å¿ƒï¼Œæœ‰é­çŠ«ã€è³ˆä½—ä»¥ç‚ºè‚¡è‚±ï¼Œæœ‰é½Šã€å®‹ã€ç§¦ã€æ¥šä»¥ç‚ºå¤–ä¸»ï¼Œæœ‰æ¬’ã€éƒ¤ã€ç‹ã€å…ˆä»¥ç‚ºå…§ä¸»ã€‚ äº¡åä¹å¹´ï¼Œå®ˆå¿—å½Œç¯¤ã€‚ æƒ ã€æ‡·æ£„æ°‘ï¼Œæ°‘å¾è€Œèˆ‡ä¹‹ã€‚ æ•…æ–‡å…¬æœ‰åœ‹ï¼Œä¸äº¦å®œä¹ï¼Ÿ å­æ¯”ç„¡æ–½æ–¼æ°‘ï¼Œç„¡æ´æ–¼å¤–ï¼Œå»æ™‰ï¼Œæ™‰ä¸é€ï¼› æ­¸æ¥šï¼Œæ¥šä¸è¿ã€‚ ä½•ä»¥æœ‰åœ‹ï¼ã€ å­æ¯”æœä¸çµ‚ç„‰ï¼Œå’ç«‹è€…æ£„ç–¾ï¼Œå¦‚å”å‘è¨€ä¹Ÿã€‚
Initially, when Zi Bi returned from Jin, Han Xuan Zi asked Shu Xiang: 'Will Zi Bi succeed?' He replied: 'He will not succeed.' Xuan Zi said: 'Like evils seek each other, like merchants in the market - why would he not succeed?' He replied: 'Without sharing good things, who shares evil? Taking a state has five difficulties: having favor but no people, one; having people but no master, two; having a master but no strategy, three; having strategy but no populace, four; having populace but no virtue, five.' Zi Bi has been in Jin for thirteen years, but Jin and Chu followers have not communicated - this can be called having no people; his clan is exhausted and relatives have rebelled - this can be called having no master; moving without cause - this can be called having no strategy; being a hostage all his life - this can be called having no populace; fleeing without beloved omens - this can be called having no virtue. The king is cruel but not cautious, Zi Bi encounters five difficulties to assassinate his lord - who can help him succeed! One who can have the state of Chu - it would be Qi Ji. He controls Chen and Cai, and the outer areas beyond Fang Cheng belong to him. Harsh and evil do not arise, thieves hide themselves, private desires are not violated, the people have no resentment. The spirits have commanded him, the people believe in him. When the Mi surname has disorder, it must be the youngest who establishes - this is Chu's constant rule. Zi Bi's office is Right Minister; counting his noble favor, he is an illegitimate son; according to the spirits' command, he is even further removed; the people do not long for him - how can he be established?' Xuan Zi said: 'Were Duke Huan of Qi and Duke Wen of Jin not also like this?' He replied: 'Duke Huan was the son of Wei Ji, favored by Duke Xi. He had Bao Shu Ya, Bin Xu Wu, Xi Peng as assistants, Ju and Wei as outer supporters, Gao and Guo as inner supporters. He followed goodness like flowing water, bestowed favors without tiring. That he obtained the state - was it not fitting? In ancient times, our Duke Wen was the son of Hu Ji, favored by Duke Xian. He studied tirelessly. At seventeen years old, he had five worthy men, had former grand master Zi Yu and Zi Fan as heart, had Wei Wu and Jia Tuo as limbs, had Qi, Song, Qin, Chu as outer supporters, had Luan, Xi, Hu, Xian as inner supporters. Exiled for nineteen years, his resolve grew even stronger. Hui and Huai abandoned the people, the people followed him. That Duke Wen obtained the state - was it not fitting? Zi Bi has done nothing for the people, has no support from outside, when he left Jin, Jin did not send him; when he returned to Chu, Chu did not welcome him. How can he obtain the state!' Zi Bi indeed did not last, and the one who finally ascended was Qi Ji, just as Shu Xiang said.

At this time, Wu She was the crown prince's Grand Tutor, Wu Ji was the Junior Tutor. Wu Ji was not favored by the crown prince and constantly slandered Crown Prince Jian. Jian was then fifteen years old, his mother was a woman from Cai, not favored by the king, so the king gradually became more distant from Jian.

In the sixth year, he sent Crown Prince Jian to reside at Cheng Fu to guard the border. Wu Ji slandered him, saying: 'Jian is plotting rebellion.' In the twenty-seventh year, spring, Wu attacked Chen, and Chu Zhao Wang rescued it, camping at Cheng Fu. In the tenth month, Zhao Wang fell ill in the army camp, with red clouds like birds flying alongside the sun. Zhao Wang asked Zhou's Grand Historian, who said: 'This bodes ill for the Chu king, but it can be transferred to the generals and ministers.' The generals and ministers heard this and requested to sacrifice themselves to the spirits. Zhao Wang said: 'Generals and ministers are my limbs - now transferring the calamity, how can I let them bear it!' He would not listen. They divined that the River was causing the trouble, and the grand masters requested to sacrifice to the River. Zhao Wang said: 'Since my ancestors received the enfeoffment, their domain did not extend beyond the Jiang and Han rivers, and the River is not something we have offended.' He stopped them and would not allow it. Confucius was in Chen and heard this, saying: 'Chu Zhao Wang understands the great Way. That he does not lose his state is fitting!'

Zhao Wang's illness grew severe, so he summoned the various princes and grand masters: 'I am unworthy, having twice brought shame to Chu's armies, now I can end with a natural lifespan - this is my good fortune.' He yielded to his younger brother Gong Zi Shen to become king, but he would not accept. He again yielded to his next younger brother Gong Zi Jie, who also would not accept. He then yielded to his next younger brother Gong Zi LÃ¼, yielding five times before he finally agreed to become king. They were about to fight when, on Geng Yin, Zhao Wang died in the army camp. Zi LÃ¼ said: 'The king was gravely ill and, abandoning his son, yielded to his ministers. I agreed to the king to broaden his intentions. Now the king has died, how dare I forget the king's intentions!' Thus he plotted with Zi Xi and Zi Qi, hid troops and blocked the roads, welcomed Yue Nu's son Zhang and established him as king, who became Hui Wang. Then they dismissed the troops and returned, burying Zhao Wang.

æƒ ç‹äºŒå¹´ï¼Œå­è¥¿å¬æ•…å¹³ç‹å¤ªå­å»ºä¹‹å­å‹æ–¼å³ï¼Œä»¥ç‚ºå·¢å¤§å¤«ï¼Œè™Ÿæ›°ç™½å…¬ã€‚ ç™½å…¬å¥½å…µè€Œä¸‹å£«ï¼Œæ¬²å ±ä»‡ã€‚ å…­å¹´ï¼Œç™½å…¬è«‹å…µä»¤å°¹å­è¥¿ä¼é„­ã€‚ åˆï¼Œç™½å…¬çˆ¶å»ºäº¡åœ¨é„­ï¼Œé„­æ®ºä¹‹ï¼Œç™½å…¬äº¡èµ°å³ï¼Œå­è¥¿å¾©å¬ä¹‹ï¼Œæ•…ä»¥æ­¤æ€¨é„­ï¼Œæ¬²ä¼ä¹‹ã€‚ å­è¥¿è¨±è€Œæœªç‚ºç™¼å…µã€‚ å…«å¹´ï¼Œæ™‰ä¼é„­ï¼Œé„­å‘Šæ€¥æ¥šï¼Œæ¥šä½¿å­è¥¿æ•‘é„­ï¼Œå—è³‚è€Œå»ã€‚ ç™½å…¬å‹æ€’ï¼Œä¹ƒé‚èˆ‡å‹‡åŠ›æ­»å£«çŸ³ä¹ç­‰è¥²æ®ºä»¤å°¹å­è¥¿ã€å­ç¶¦æ–¼æœï¼Œå› åŠ«æƒ ç‹ï¼Œç½®ä¹‹é«˜åºœï¼Œæ¬²å¼’ä¹‹ã€‚ æƒ ç‹å¾è€…å±ˆå›ºè² ç‹äº¡èµ°æ˜­ç‹å¤«äººå®®ã€‚ ç™½å…¬è‡ªç«‹ç‚ºç‹ã€‚ æœˆé¤˜ï¼Œæœƒè‘‰å…¬ä¾†æ•‘æ¥šï¼Œæ¥šæƒ ç‹ä¹‹å¾’èˆ‡å…±æ”»ç™½å…¬ï¼Œæ®ºä¹‹ã€‚ æƒ ç‹ä¹ƒå¾©ä½ã€‚ æ˜¯æ­²ä¹Ÿï¼Œæ»…é™³è€Œç¸£ä¹‹ã€‚
In Hui Wang's second year, Zi Xi summoned the former Ping Wang Crown Prince Jian's son Sheng from Wu to be the Nest grand master, calling him Bai Gong. Bai Gong loved military affairs and treated worthy men well, desiring to avenge his grievances. In the sixth year, Bai Gong requested troops from Prime Minister Zi Xi to attack Zheng. Initially, Bai Gong's father Jian had fled to Zheng, where Zheng killed him, so Bai Gong fled to Wu, and Zi Xi again summoned him, thus he resented Zheng and wanted to attack it. Zi Xi gave him troops, and Bai Gong defeated Zheng and took Xiang Ling. He returned and attacked Zheng again, defeating them at Fang Cheng. He was arrogant and wanted to seize the Chu government. Zi Xi feared this and did not give him more troops. Bai Gong then allied with Qi Zhao and attacked Zi Xi and Zi Qi, killing them. He seized the Chu capital and summoned Hui Wang from Cheng Fu. Hui Wang feared and fled to Sui, then to Cai. Bai Gong established himself as king.

Hui Wang was restored, and he granted Yin Qi the surname Wang Sun. In Hui Wang's tenth year, he died, and his son Jian Wang Sheng ascended the throne.

In the fourth year, You Wang died, and his son Ai Wang Shen ascended the throne. Ai Wang's first year, he attacked Song. Chen Zhen happened to be serving as Qin envoy to Qi, and the Qi king said: 'What should we do?' Chen Zhen said: 'Your Majesty need not worry, please allow me to make them withdraw.' He immediately went to see Zhao Yang in the army camp, saying: 'I wish to hear about Chu's laws - what rank is given to those who break armies and kill generals?' Zhao Yang said: 'Their office becomes Upper Pillar State, sealed with upper nobility holding the jade tablet.' Chen Zhen said: 'Is there anything more noble than this?' Zhao Yang said: 'Prime Minister.' Chen Zhen said: 'Now you have already become Prime Minister - this is the highest position in the state. Allow me to give you a parable. There was someone who left his servants a cup of wine. The servants said to each other: 'Several people drinking this would not be enough to go around, so let us draw a snake on the ground - the one who finishes the snake first will drink it alone.' One man said: 'My snake is finished first.' He picked up the wine and stood up, saying: 'I can add feet to it.' When he came to add the feet, another person snatched the wine and drank it, saying: 'A snake has no feet - now that you've added feet, this is not a snake.' Now you are Prime Minister of Chu attacking Wei, breaking their army and killing their general - no merit could be greater, the highest position cannot be added to. Now if you shift troops to attack Qi, and if you attack Qi and win, your office and nobility will not be added to this; if you attack but do not win, you will die and lose your nobility, bringing ruin to Chu - this is the story of adding feet to the snake. It would be better to lead troops away and show virtue to Qi - this is the way to hold fullness.' Zhao Yang said: 'Good.' He led his troops away.

Yan and Han lords first proclaimed themselves kings. Qin sent Zhang Yi to meet with Chu, Qi, and Wei, forming an alliance at Nie Sang.

åä¸€å¹´ï¼Œè˜‡ç§¦ç´„å¾å±±æ±å…­åœ‹å…±æ”»ç§¦ï¼Œæ¥šæ‡·ç‹ç‚ºå¾é•·ã€‚ è‡³å‡½è°·é—œï¼Œç§¦å‡ºå…µæ“Šå…­åœ‹ï¼Œå…­åœ‹å…µçš†å¼•è€Œæ­¸ï¼Œé½Šç¨å¾Œã€‚ åäºŒå¹´ï¼Œé½Šæ¹£ç‹ä¼æ•—è¶™ã€é­è»ï¼Œç§¦äº¦ä¼æ•—éŸ“ï¼Œèˆ‡é½Šçˆ­é•·ã€‚
In the eleventh year, Su Qin united the six states east of the mountains to attack Qin together, with Chu Hui Wang as the alliance leader. They reached the Hangu Pass, Qin sent troops to attack the six states, and the six states' troops all retreated and returned, with Qi alone coming last. In the twelfth year, Qi Min Wang attacked and defeated Zhao and Wei's armies, while Qin also attacked and defeated Han, contending with Qi for leadership.

åå…­å¹´ï¼Œç§¦æ¬²ä¼é½Šï¼Œè€Œæ¥šèˆ‡é½Šå¾è¦ªï¼Œç§¦æƒ ç‹æ‚£ä¹‹ï¼Œä¹ƒå®£è¨€å¼µå„€å…ç›¸ï¼Œä½¿å¼µå„€å—è¦‹æ¥šç‹ï¼Œè¬‚æ¥šç‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ•é‚‘ä¹‹ç‹æ‰€ç”šèªªè€…ç„¡å…ˆå¤§ç‹ï¼Œé›–å„€ä¹‹æ‰€ç”šé¡˜ç‚ºé–€é—Œä¹‹å»è€…äº¦ç„¡å…ˆå¤§ç‹ã€‚ æ•é‚‘ä¹‹ç‹æ‰€ç”šæ†è€…ç„¡å…ˆé½Šç‹ï¼Œé›–å„€ä¹‹æ‰€ç”šæ†è€…äº¦ç„¡å…ˆé½Šç‹ã€‚ è€Œå¤§ç‹å’Œä¹‹ï¼Œæ˜¯ä»¥æ•é‚‘ä¹‹ç‹ä¸å¾—äº‹ç‹ï¼Œè€Œä»¤å„€äº¦ä¸å¾—ç‚ºé–€é—Œä¹‹å»ä¹Ÿã€‚ ç‹ç‚ºå„€é–‰é—œè€Œçµ•é½Šï¼Œä»Šä½¿ä½¿è€…å¾å„€è¥¿å–ç¬”ç§¦æ‰€åˆ†æ¥šå•†æ–¼ä¹‹åœ°æ–¹å…­ç™¾é‡Œï¼Œå¦‚æ˜¯å‰‡é½Šå¼±çŸ£ã€‚ æ˜¯åŒ—å¼±é½Šï¼Œè¥¿å¾·æ–¼ç§¦ï¼Œç§å•†æ–¼ä»¥ç‚ºå¯Œï¼Œæ­¤ä¸€è¨ˆè€Œä¸‰åˆ©ä¿±è‡³ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ æ‡·ç‹å¤§æ‚…ï¼Œä¹ƒç½®ç›¸ç’½æ–¼å¼µå„€ï¼Œæ—¥èˆ‡ç½®é…’ï¼Œå®£è¨€ã€Œå¾å¾©å¾—å¾å•†æ–¼ä¹‹åœ°ã€ã€‚ ç¾¤è‡£çš†è³€ï¼Œè€Œé™³è»«ç¨å¼”ã€‚ æ‡·ç‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œä½•æ•…ï¼Ÿã€ é™³è»«å°æ›°ï¼šã€Œç§¦ä¹‹æ‰€ç‚ºé‡ç‹è€…ï¼Œä»¥ç‹ä¹‹æœ‰é½Šä¹Ÿã€‚ ä»Šåœ°æœªå¯å¾—è€Œé½Šäº¤å…ˆçµ•ï¼Œæ˜¯æ¥šå­¤ä¹Ÿã€‚ å¤«ç§¦åˆä½•é‡å­¤åœ‹å“‰ï¼Œå¿…è¼•æ¥šçŸ£ã€‚ ä¸”å…ˆå‡ºåœ°è€Œå¾Œçµ•é½Šï¼Œå‰‡ç§¦è¨ˆä¸ç‚ºã€‚ å…ˆçµ•é½Šè€Œå¾Œè²¬åœ°ï¼Œå‰‡å¿…è¦‹æ¬ºæ–¼å¼µå„€ã€‚ è¦‹æ¬ºæ–¼å¼µå„€ï¼Œå‰‡ç‹å¿…æ€¨ä¹‹ã€‚ æ€¨ä¹‹ï¼Œæ˜¯è¥¿èµ·ç§¦æ‚£ï¼ŒåŒ—çµ•é½Šäº¤ã€‚ è¥¿èµ·ç§¦æ‚£ï¼ŒåŒ—çµ•é½Šäº¤ï¼Œå‰‡å…©åœ‹ä¹‹å…µå¿…è‡³ã€‚ è‡£æ•…å¼”ã€‚ã€ æ¥šç‹å¼—è½ï¼Œå› ä½¿ä¸€å°‡è»è¥¿å—å°åœ°ã€‚
In the sixteenth year, Qin wished to attack Qi, but Chu was allied with Qi, so Qin Hui Wang was troubled by this. He proclaimed that Zhang Yi was dismissed as prime minister, and sent Zhang Yi south to see the Chu king, telling him: 'What my king most delights in has no precedence over the Great King, and what I most wish to be is a gatekeeper for the Great King. What my king most hates has no precedence over the Qi king, and what I most hate also has no precedence over the Qi king. But the Great King is allied with him, which is why my king cannot serve the Great King, and I also cannot be a gatekeeper. May the Great King close his gates and break with Qi for my sake. Now I will send envoys with me west to take the six hundred li of Shang Yu land that Qin divided from Chu, and give it back to you. Thus Qi will be weakened. This weakens Qi to the north, shows favor to Qin in the west, and privately gets Shang Yu back for enrichment - this is one plan that achieves three benefits.' Hui Wang was greatly pleased and placed the prime minister's seal on Zhang Yi, drinking with him daily, proclaiming 'I have regained my Shang Yu land.' All the ministers congratulated him, but Chen Zhen alone mourned. Hui Wang said: 'Why?' Chen Zhen replied: 'What Qin values in the king is that he has Qi as an ally. Now the land cannot be obtained but the Qi alliance is broken first - this isolates Chu. Why would Qin value an isolated state? They will surely despise Chu. Moreover, if we get the land first and then break with Qi, Qin's plan will not succeed. If we break with Qi first and then demand the land, we will surely be deceived by Zhang Yi. Being deceived by Zhang Yi, the king will surely resent him. Resenting him means raising troubles with Qin in the west and breaking the alliance with Qi in the north. Raising troubles with Qin in the west and breaking the alliance with Qi in the north means both states' armies will surely come. Therefore I mourn.' The Chu king would not listen, so he sent a general west to receive the sealed land.

Zhang Yi arrived in Qin, pretended to be drunk and fall from his chariot, claiming illness and not coming out for three months, so the land could not be obtained. The Chu king said: 'Does Zhang Yi think breaking with Qi is still too little?' So he sent the brave warrior Song Yi north to insult the Qi king. The Qi king was greatly angered, broke the Chu alliance tablet, and allied with Qin. Qin and Qi allied, then Zhang Yi rose from his sickbed to court, telling the Chu general: 'Why do you not receive the land? From such-and-such to such-and-such, six li wide.' The Chu general said: 'I was commanded to receive six hundred li, not six li.' He returned and reported to Hui Wang. Hui Wang was greatly angered and raised troops to attack Qin. Zhang Yi said to Qin: 'Please give me a few days, I will get Chu to send troops to Han and Wei, then Qin can attack them.' Zhang Yi went to see Hui Wang, saying: 'The land is already given to you, why attack Qin?' Hui Wang said: 'I do not dare receive six li - I must receive the six hundred li.' Zhang Yi said: 'You never lost six hundred li to Qin - how can you receive it? Qin gives you six li out of kindness.' Hui Wang was angry and would not listen, sending troops to attack Qin, taking Qin land.

äºŒåå››å¹´ï¼Œå€é½Šè€Œåˆç§¦ã€‚ ç§¦æ˜­ç‹åˆç«‹ï¼Œä¹ƒåšè³‚æ–¼æ¥šã€‚ æ¥šå¾€è¿å©¦ã€‚ äºŒåäº”å¹´ï¼Œæ‡·ç‹å…¥èˆ‡ç§¦æ˜­ç‹ç›Ÿï¼Œç´„æ–¼é»ƒæ£˜ã€‚ ç§¦å¾©èˆ‡æ¥šä¸Šåº¸ã€‚ äºŒåå…­å¹´ï¼Œé½Šã€éŸ“ã€é­ç‚ºæ¥šè² å…¶å¾è¦ªè€Œåˆæ–¼ç§¦ï¼Œä¸‰åœ‹å…±ä¼æ¥šã€‚ æ¥šä½¿å¤ªå­å…¥è³ªæ–¼ç§¦è€Œè«‹æ•‘ã€‚ ç§¦ä¹ƒé£å®¢å¿é€šå°‡å…µæ•‘æ¥šï¼Œä¸‰åœ‹å¼•å…µå»ã€‚

äºŒåä¸ƒå¹´ï¼Œç§¦å¤§å¤«æœ‰ç§èˆ‡æ¥šå¤ªå­é¬¬ï¼Œæ¥šå¤ªå­æ®ºä¹‹è€Œäº¡æ­¸ã€‚ äºŒåå…«å¹´ï¼Œç§¦ä¹ƒèˆ‡é½Šã€éŸ“ã€é­å…±æ”»æ¥šï¼Œæ®ºæ¥šå°‡å”çœ›ï¼Œå–æˆ‘é‡ä¸˜è€Œå»ã€‚ äºŒåä¹å¹´ï¼Œç§¦å¾©æ”»æ¥šï¼Œå¤§ç ´æ¥šï¼Œæ¥šè»æ­»è€…äºŒè¬ï¼Œæ®ºæˆ‘å°‡è»æ™¯ç¼ºã€‚ æ‡·ç‹æï¼Œä¹ƒä½¿å¤ªå­ç‚ºè³ªæ–¼é½Šä»¥æ±‚å¹³ã€‚ ä¸‰åå¹´ï¼Œç§¦å¾©ä¼æ¥šï¼Œå–å…«åŸã€‚ ç§¦æ˜­ç‹éºæ¥šç‹æ›¸æ›°ï¼šã€Œå§‹å¯¡äººèˆ‡ç‹ç´„ç‚ºå¼Ÿå…„ï¼Œç›Ÿäºé»ƒæ£˜ï¼Œå¤ªå­ç‚ºè³ªï¼Œè‡³é©©ä¹Ÿã€‚ å¤ªå­é™µæ®ºå¯¡äººä¹‹é‡è‡£ï¼Œä¸è¬è€Œäº¡å»ï¼Œå¯¡äººèª ä¸å‹æ€’ï¼Œä½¿å…µä¾µå›ç‹ä¹‹é‚Šã€‚ ä»Šèå›ç‹ä¹ƒä»¤å¤ªå­è³ªæ–¼é½Šä»¥æ±‚å¹³ã€‚ å¯¡äººèˆ‡æ¥šæ¥å¢ƒå£¤ç•Œï¼Œæ•…ç‚ºå©šå§»ï¼Œæ‰€å¾ç›¸è¦ªä¹…çŸ£ã€‚ è€Œä»Šç§¦æ¥šä¸é©©ï¼Œå‰‡ç„¡ä»¥ä»¤è«¸ä¾¯ã€‚ å¯¡äººé¡˜èˆ‡å›ç‹æœƒæ­¦é—œï¼Œé¢ç›¸ç´„ï¼Œçµç›Ÿè€Œå»ï¼Œå¯¡äººä¹‹é¡˜ä¹Ÿã€‚ æ•¢ä»¥èä¸‹åŸ·äº‹ã€‚ã€ æ¥šæ‡·ç‹è¦‹ç§¦ç‹æ›¸ï¼Œæ‚£ä¹‹ã€‚ æ¬²å¾€ï¼Œæè¦‹æ¬ºï¼› ç„¡å¾€ï¼Œæç§¦æ€’ã€‚ æ˜­é›æ›°ï¼šã€Œç‹æ¯‹è¡Œï¼Œè€Œç™¼å…µè‡ªå®ˆè€³ã€‚ ç§¦è™ç‹¼ï¼Œä¸å¯ä¿¡ï¼Œæœ‰å¹¶è«¸ä¾¯ä¹‹å¿ƒã€‚ã€ æ‡·ç‹å­å­è˜­å‹¸ç‹è¡Œï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€ŒæŸ°ä½•çµ•ç§¦ä¹‹é©©å¿ƒï¼ã€ æ–¼æ˜¯å¾€æœƒç§¦æ˜­ç‹ã€‚ æ˜­ç‹è©ä»¤ä¸€å°‡è»ä¼å…µæ­¦é—œï¼Œè™Ÿç‚ºç§¦ç‹ã€‚ æ¥šç‹è‡³ï¼Œå‰‡é–‰æ­¦é—œï¼Œé‚èˆ‡è¥¿è‡³å’¸é™½ï¼Œæœç« è‡ºï¼Œå¦‚è•ƒè‡£ï¼Œä¸èˆ‡äº¢ç¦®ã€‚ æ¥šæ‡·ç‹å¤§æ€’ï¼Œæ‚”ä¸ç”¨æ˜­å­è¨€ã€‚ ç§¦å› ç•™æ¥šç‹ï¼Œè¦ä»¥å‰²å·«ã€é»”ä¸­ä¹‹éƒ¡ã€‚ æ¥šç‹æ¬²ç›Ÿï¼Œç§¦æ¬²å…ˆå¾—åœ°ã€‚ æ¥šç‹æ€’æ›°ï¼šã€Œç§¦è©æˆ‘è€Œåˆå½Šè¦æˆ‘ä»¥åœ°ï¼ã€ ä¸å¾©è¨±ç§¦ã€‚ ç§¦å› ç•™ä¹‹ã€‚
In the twenty-seventh year, a Qin grand master privately fought with the Chu crown prince, and the Chu crown prince killed him and fled back. In the twenty-eighth year, Qin then allied with Qi, Han, and Wei to attack Chu together, killing the Chu general Tang Mei and taking Chu's Chong Qiu before leaving. In the twenty-ninth year, Qin again attacked Chu, greatly defeating them, with twenty thousand Chu soldiers dying and killing Chu's general Jing Que. Hui Wang was afraid and sent the crown prince as hostage to Qi to seek peace. In the thirtieth year, Qin again attacked Chu, taking eight cities. Qin Zhao Wang sent a letter to the Chu king: 'Initially I and the king agreed to be brothers, forming an alliance at Huang Ji, with the crown prince as hostage - this was very pleasant. The crown prince arrogantly killed my important minister without apologizing and fled away. I truly cannot contain my anger, so I sent troops to invade the king's borders. Now I hear the king has sent the crown prince as hostage to Qi to seek peace. I and Chu share bordering lands, so we intermarried, and our alliance has been close for a long time. But now Qin and Chu are not on good terms, which makes it impossible to command the feudal lords. I wish to meet the king at Wu Guan, make a face-to-face agreement, form an alliance, and leave - this is my wish. I dare to inform your officials.' Chu Hui Wang saw Qin's letter and was troubled by it. He wanted to go but feared being deceived; if he did not go, he feared Qin would be angry. Zhao Sui said: 'Your Majesty should not go, but raise troops to defend yourself. Qin is like a tiger or wolf, cannot be trusted - they have intentions to swallow the feudal lords.' Hui Wang's son Zi Lan urged the king to go, saying: 'How can we break Qin's friendly intentions!' Therefore he went to meet Qin Zhao Wang. Zhao Wang deceitfully ordered a general to hide troops at Wu Guan, calling himself Qin Wang. When the Chu king arrived, they closed Wu Guan and escorted him west to Xian Yang, where he attended court at Zhang Tai like a vassal, without equal ritual. Chu Hui Wang was greatly angered and regretted not listening to Zhao Sui's words. Qin detained the Chu king and demanded the cession of the Wu and Qian Zhong commanderies. The Chu king wanted to form an alliance, but Qin wanted to get the land first. The Chu king angrily said: 'Qin has deceived me and now forcibly demands land from me!' He would not agree to Qin again. Qin therefore detained him.

The Chu ministers were troubled and plotted together: 'Our king is in Qin and cannot return, they demand the cession of land, and the crown prince is hostage in Qi. If Qi and Qin conspire together, then Chu will have no state.' They wanted to establish a son of Hui Wang who was in the country. Zhao Sui said: 'The king and crown prince are both trapped by the feudal lords, and now if we go against the king's command and establish his illegitimate son, it is not proper.' He deceitfully reported to Qi that Qi Min Wang told his prime minister: 'It would be better to detain the crown prince to demand Chu's Huai Bei.' The prime minister said: 'This cannot be done. If Ying establishes a king, then we are holding an empty hostage and acting unjustly toward the world.' Some said: 'Not so. If Ying establishes a king, then bargain with their new king saying 'Give me the lower eastern region, and I will have the king kill the crown prince, otherwise I will ally with the three states to establish him', then the eastern region can surely be obtained.' Qi Wang ultimately used his prime minister's plan and returned the Chu crown prince. The crown prince Heng arrived and was established as king, becoming Qing Xiang Wang. He announced to Qin: 'Relying on the spirits of the altars of soil and grain, the state has a king.'

Sima Qian said: When Chu Ling Wang was assembling the feudal lords at Shen, executing Qi Qing Feng, building the Zhang Hua Terrace, and seeking the Zhou nine ding tripods, his ambitions encompassed the whole world; yet he starved to death in Shen Hai's house, becoming a laughingstock to the world. That his conduct could not achieve this - how sad! Can one not be careful about power's influence on people? Qi Ji established himself through disorder, doted on and was corrupted by the Qin woman - how extreme! He nearly destroyed the state twice!
